The man beside her was unfamiliar, his arm casually draped around her shoulders, their laughter captured in a frozen moment. I found myself gritting my teeth, my jaw clenched so tightly it began to ache. This wasn't how things were supposed to be. I had envisioned our life together as a seamless tapestry of shared history and mutual understanding. Yet here was a thread that didn't fit, a mystery that shouldn't exist in the first place.

I felt a rising anger, fueled by the sense that something had been taken from me, something that I believed was rightfully mine: control over our shared past. It was an irrational thought, but it burned nonetheless, intense and unwavering like the glow of the computer screen in the darkened room. This wasn't how things were supposed to be. And yet, here they were, staring back at me in all their improper glory.

Triggering Event: Every Sunday, he would meticulously wash and polish her favorite teapot, despite knowing she was never coming back to their kitchen. Today, as he wiped it dry, a chip caught his eye - one he'd forgotten about until now. He'd chipped it years ago in a careless moment of distractedness. Her reproachful words echoed in his mind, "Be careful, dear. It's your mother's." Remorse surged through him like a wave, drowning out the ticking clock.
Generated Assessment:
**Writing Prompt:** Describe his reaction as he notices the chip on the teapot.

---

**Text:**

He froze, hand mid-air, as if her voice had physically stopped him. "Be careful, dear," she'd said, years ago, when he was clumsy and young. He could see her now, eyes wide with worry, fingers tracing the curve of the teapot like it was precious porcelain.

"Damn it all," he muttered, his reflection glaring back at him in the polished surface. "She always knew what I'd do before I did." The chip was a silent accusation, mocking him with her memory. He could almost hear her disappointment, feel her disapproval. How many times had she warned him? Too many to count.

He set the teapot down gently, as if she were watching from somewhere unseen, waiting for him to prove her right again. The room was quiet except for his racing heart and the clock's steady ticking, each second a reminder of his carelessness.

His eyes flicked back to the chip. It was small, barely noticeable unless you knew where to look. But she'd known, hadn't she? She always did. He could almost hear her saying it, "I told you so." His stomach twisted with guilt and shame, as if her words were echoing in the empty room.

He took a deep breath, steeling himself for what he had to do next - hide the teapot away where no one else would see his mistake. Where she wouldn't see it, couldn't disapprove from beyond the grave. It wasn't fair, but then again, life never was. Not when you could hear her voice in every corner of your mind.

Triggering Event: While walking to her lab, she spots her ex-husband, now married to her former best friend, in the university café, laughing over coffee.
Generated Assessment:
**Writing Prompt:**
Imagine you're a middle-aged woman, once married to your college sweetheart who's now laughing with your former best friend in the university café. You've been divorced for years, but it still stings. Describe your immediate thoughts and feelings as you walk by them.

---

As I rounded the corner towards my lab, I saw them through the glass wall of the café - Steve, my ex-husband, laughing with that bitch, Jessica, his new wife, my former best friend. My heart stopped for a second, then restarted like a punch to the chest. What the fuck are they laughing about? It's not funny, none of this is funny.

I quickened my pace, but I could feel their eyes on me as I passed by. Did they know I saw them? They must have. Why else would they be so damn loud, so damn happy? It's like they're rubbing it in my face, like they're laughing at me.

I can't believe she moved into our old house with him. Can't believe he lets her wear that stupid necklace I bought him for our anniversary. It makes me sick to see them like that, all cozy and shit, like they don't know how much it hurts. Like they didn't promise we'd be together forever.

I guess some promises aren't meant to be kept. But does he have to flaunt it in my face? Does she have to look so damn happy about it? I just want to scream at them, "This isn't funny! Don't you understand how much this hurts?" But I don't say anything. I just keep walking, because what's the point? They don't care. They never did.

My lab feels cold and empty now. I sit down at my desk, but I can't focus on work. All I can see is them laughing together. And even though I know it's ridiculous, a little voice in my head whispers, "They're laughing at you. This is all your fault."
